case_name: State of Kerala v. N. Sami Iyer

facts.text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Kerala in Tax Revenue Case No. 44 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Sikri, J. This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Kerala in Tax Revenue Case No. 44 of 1960. The respondent, N. Sami Iyer, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, is a dealer in tobacco.

facts.text: The respondent, N. Sami Iyer, is a dealer in tobacco.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, N. Sami Iyer, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, is a dealer in tobacco.

facts.text: Assessee objected to the assessment of turnover of Rs. 7,757.54 for assessment year 1957-58 on ground that goods were already assessed at point of purchase.

anchor.surface_text: He objected to the assessment of the turnover of Rs. 7,757.54 for the assessment year 1957-58, inter alia, on the ground that the goods were the subject-matter of purchases which had already been assessed at the point of purchase in the hands of the assessee.

facts.text: Assessee failed before the Sales Tax authorities.

anchor.surface_text: He failed before the Sales Tax authorities, but in a revision the High Court accepted his contention and held that this turnover was not liable to tax.

facts.text: High Court accepted assessee's contention and held turnover not liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: He failed before the Sales Tax authorities, but in a revision the High Court accepted his contention and held that this turnover was not liable to tax.

facts.text: During April 1, 1957 to September 30, 1957, assessee resided in Malabar where Madras General Sales Tax Act 9 of 1939 applied.

anchor.surface_text: During the period April 1, 1957 to September 30, 1957, the assessee was residing in Malabar and in this area the Madras General Sales Tax Act 9 of 1939 applied.

facts.text: Tobacco was taxable at the purchase point under the Madras Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that tobacco was taxable at the purchase point under the Madras Act and that the turnover with which we are concerned had suffered taxation at that point under the Madras Act.

facts.text: The turnover concerned suffered taxation at purchase point under Madras Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that tobacco was taxable at the purchase point under the Madras Act and that the turnover with which we are concerned had suffered taxation at that point under the Madras Act.

facts.text: Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1957 (12 of 1957) came into force on October 1, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1957 12 of 1957 came into force on October 1, 1957.

facts.text: Act 12 of 1957 extended the Act to whole State of Kerala including Malabar district.

anchor.surface_text: This Act changed the short title of the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act 1125 11 of 1125 to the General Sales Tax Act, 1125, and extended it to the whole of the State of Kerala, including Malabar district.

facts.text: Section 14 of Act 12 of 1957 inserted s. 26A in Act 11 of 1125 with transitory provisions.

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 of Act 12 of 1957 inserted s. 26A in Act 11 of 1125 which reads as follows 26A. Transitory provisions.

facts.text: Schedule II to s.26A deems registrations and licences under Madras Act in Malabar to be under this Act.

anchor.surface_text: Schedule II is in the following terms Every registration effected and every licence issued under the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 or the rules made thereunder in their application to the Malabar District... shall be deemed to have been effected or issued under this Act or the rules made thereunder.

facts.text: For financial year ending 31 March 1958, turnover under Madras Act up to Oct 1, 1957 to be included in total turnover under General Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: In calculating the total turnover for the financial year ending with 31st March 1958 of a dealer in the Malabar area for purposes of sub-section 3 of section 3 of this Act, the turnover of the dealer under the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 up to the commencement of the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Amendment Act, 1957, shall also be taken into account.

facts.text: Act 12 of 1957 repealed Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 in Malabar District.

anchor.surface_text: The 12 of 1957, by s. 15 inter alia repealed the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939, as in force in the Malabar District...

facts.text: Section 5(vii) of General Sales Tax Act specifies single point of tax for goods in Schedule I.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 vii of the General Sales Tax Act corresponding to s. 5 of the Madras General Sale Tax Act provides as follows The sale of goods specified in column 2 of schedule I shall be liable to tax under section 3, sub-section 1 only at such single point...

facts.text: Item 2 in column 2 of Schedule I: Tobacco other than Beedi Tobacco Suka.

anchor.surface_text: The description of item 2 in column 2 of Schedule I at the relevant time was Tobacco other than Beedi Tobacco Suka .

facts.text: Government notification No. RI-10674/57/RD-2 dated September 28, 1957 specified taxable point for tobacco as 1st sale in the State by dealer not exempt.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers conferred by section 5 vii the Government issued a notification No. RI-10674/57/RD-2 dated September 28, 1957. ... Tobacco other than Beedi Tobacco Suka 1st sale in the State by a dealer who is not exempt from taxation under section 3 3 .

facts.text: Previously under Madras Act, taxable point for tobacco was first purchase.

anchor.surface_text: The result of the above notification is that whereas previously the taxable point in respect of tobacco was the point of first purchase under the Madras Act, now the taxable point is the first sale in the State.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that turnover of Rs. 7,754.54 is not liable to taxation.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we agree with the High Court that the turn-over of Rs. 7,754.54 is not liable to taxation.

facts.text: Section 3(5) of Madras Act and General Sales Tax Act, 1125 are in the same terms.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 5 of the General Sales Tax Act, 1125, is in the same terms as s. 3 5 of the Madras General Sales Tax Act, reproduced as above.

facts.text: Proviso to s.3(5) of Madras Act: where dealer taxed on purchase, not taxed again on sale.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 5 of this Act provides The taxes under sub-sections 1 , 1-A and 2 shall be assessed... Provided that - In respect of the same transaction of sale, the buyer or the seller, but not both... Where a dealer has been taxed in respect of the purchase of any goods... he shall not be taxed again in respect of any sale of such goods effected by him.

facts.text: Appellant argued no vested right to be taxed only under Madras Act.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate-General... has raised two points... first, that in this case there was no right, much less a vested right, not to be taxed except under the Madras General Sales Tax Act...

facts.text: Appellant argued Act 12 of 1957 manifests contrary intention under s.4(c) General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, he says that even if there was such a right, Act 12 of 1957 manifests a contrary and different intention within the meaning of s. 4 c of the General Clauses Act, 1125...

facts.text: Supreme Court repels appellant's first argument.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we repel the first argument of the learned Advocate-General.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds no intention in Act 12 of 1957 to destroy rights under Madras Act.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot discern any intention in Act 12 of 1957 to destroy the rights and liabilities acquired or incurred under the Madras General Sales Tax Act. The second schedule... shows that the intention was to preserve old rights...
This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment

As observed by this Court in State of Punjab v. Mohar Singh , when the repeal is followed by fresh legislation on the same subject we should undoubtedly have to look to the provisions of the Act, but only for the purpose of determining whether they indicate a different intention. The line of enquiry would be number whether the new Act expressly keeps alive old rights and liabilities but whether it manifests an intention to destroy them.

concepts.interpretation: New legislation must manifest intention to destroy old rights/liabilities under repealed Act; here no such intention.

arguments.claim: The turnover of Rs. 7,757.54 for 1957-58 is not liable to tax because the goods were already assessed at the point of purchase in the hands of the assessee under the Madras General Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: He objected to the assessment of the turnover of Rs. 7,757.54 for the assessment year 1957-58, inter alia, on the ground that the goods were the subject-matter of purchases which had already been assessed at the point of purchase in the hands of the assessee.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees with High Court holding; rights and liabilities under repealed Act preserved absent contrary intention.

arguments.claim: The assessee's contention is correct and the turnover is not liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: He failed before the Sales Tax authorities, but in a revision the High Court accepted his contention and held that this turnover was not liable to tax.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees with the High Court.

arguments.court_reasoning: Liability under Madras Act continues with attached right not to be taxed again on sale by virtue of s.4(c) General Clauses Act.

arguments.claim: Even if such a right existed, Act 12 of 1957 manifests a contrary and different intention within s.4(c) of the General Clauses Act, 1125, making the disputed turnover liable to tax under Act 12 of 1957.

arguments.court_reasoning: No intention to destroy rights under Madras Act; Schedule II preserves old rights like registrations; Legislature would have used clear words if intended to override.

arguments.claim: Under s.4(c) General Clauses Act, the dealer continued liable under Madras Act for purchase taxation, with attached right not to be taxed again on sale of same goods.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that by virtue of s. 4 c the dealer continued to be liable to taxation under the Madras General Sales Tax Act in respect of the disputed turnover at the purchase point...

arguments.claim: Act 12 of 1957 does not manifest a different intention to destroy rights and liabilities under the repealed Madras General Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The next question that arises is whether Act 12 of 1957 manifests a different intention. As observed by this Court in State of Punjab v. Mohar Singh , when the repeal is followed by fresh legislation...

arguments.claim: Schedule II to s.26A shows legislative intention to preserve old rights and liabilities such as registrations and licences under Madras Act.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot discern any intention in Act 12 of 1957 to destroy the rights and liabilities acquired or incurred under the Madras General Sales Tax Act. The second schedule reproduced above shows that the intention was to preserve old rights...

holdings.text: By virtue of s.4(c) of the General Clauses Act, the dealer continued to be liable to taxation under the Madras General Sales Tax Act in respect of the disputed turnover at the purchase point, with an attached right not to be taxed again in respect of any sale of such goods.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that by virtue of s. 4 c  the dealer continued to be liable to taxation under the Madras General Sales Tax Act in respect of the disputed turnover at the purchase point. For example, if for some reason he had not been assessed before Act 12 of 1957 came into force, he would have been assessed under the Madras Act at the purchase point because a liability within the meaning of s. 4 c  would have been incurred by him. To this liability would be attached a right the right being that he would not be liable to be taxed in respect of any sale of goods which had been the subject-matter of a purchase and taxation under the Madras Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liability incurred under MGSTA at purchase point carries attached right under proviso to s.3(5) not to be taxed on subsequent sale; preserved by s.4(c) GCA upon repeal.

holdings.text: Act 12 of 1957 does not manifest any intention to destroy the rights and liabilities acquired or incurred under the repealed Madras General Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we repel the first argument of the learned Advocate-General. The next question that arises is whether Act 12 of 1957 manifests a different intention. As observed by this Court in State of Punjab v. Mohar Singh , when the repeal is followed by fresh legislation on the same subject we should undoubtedly have to look to the provisions of the Act, but only for the purpose of determining whether they indicate a different intention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Schedule II preserves prior rights like registrations; no express words to override rights under MGSTA s.3(5); following precedent on contrary intention doctrine.

holdings.text: The turnover of Rs. 7,754.54 is not liable to taxation.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we agree with the High Court that the turn-over of Rs. 7,754.54 is not liable to taxation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying preserved rights under MGSTA via GCA s.4(c), absent contrary intention in Act 12 of 1957, turnover already taxed at purchase not taxable on sale.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that by virtue of s. 4 c  the dealer continued to be liable to taxation under the Madras General Sales Tax Act in respect of the disputed turnover at the purchase point. For example, if for some reason he had not been assessed before Act 12 of 1957 came into force, he would have been assessed under the Madras Act at the purchase point because a liability within the meaning of s. 4 c  would have been incurred by him. To this liability would be attached a right the right being that he would not be liable to be taxed in respect of any sale of goods which had been the subject-matter of a purchase and taxation under the Madras Act.
In the result we agree with the High Court that the turn-over of Rs. 7,754.54 is number liable to taxation.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we repel the first argument of the learned Advocate-General. The next question that arises is whether Act 12 of 1957 manifests a different intention. As observed by this Court in State of Punjab v. Mohar Singh , when the repeal is followed by fresh legislation on the same subject we should undoubtedly have to look to the provisions of the Act, but only for the purpose of determining whether they indicate a different intention.
